timeline.bodyText: This is a breaking API change. I think it's ok, but it should have an entry in changes.yaml (see the equivalent file in the 5_0_0 changelog directory) and a JavaDoc saying @since 5.1.0
timeline.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Suggested change * An IBaseResource that has a FHIR version of DSTU3 or higher * An IBaseResource that is using an org.hl7.fhir.* structure, as opposed to the ca.uhn.fhir.model.* structures that are used for DSTU2 and below in HAPI FHIR.
timeline.author: jamesagnew
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -23,6 +23,9 @@
  * #L%
  */
 
+/**
+ * An IBaseResource that has a FHIR version of DSTU3 or higher

timeline.bodyText: Heh, this is a lot of these to review, but what a great change!
timeline.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Are there really enough beans that we need this? Can we just explicitly declare them? Maybe in a dedicated context file in the EMPI project that gets imported here?
timeline.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: This is an exclude.  Empi does not @ComponentScan.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: Sorry, missed that fact. Resolving this.
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText:
I have never seen this query-by-Example thing before. Strangely named, but kinda neat.
It does kind of give me pause if I'm honest though:

This is a different query pattern to how we do everything else, and
It really obscures which columns are used for SELECTs which makes it hard to tell if the indexes added to the tables are appropriate, when compared to just putting standard @Query methods on the repository interface

I'm not necessarily saying to do anything about this comment, but I don't know that this is a query pattern we want to propagate without considering the consequences..
timeline.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: It becomes particularly useful in the $empi-query-links operation where there are 4 parameters that are all nullable and you want to be able to query by all 4 of them.  Beats 16 @Query methods.
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText:
Fair enough. I guess I'll restate this comment to just be:
Make sure you have appropriate indexes for any columns being searched on :)
replies.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: Following the rule of thumb "If you are reading more than 5% of the records from a table, then a full table scan will be faster than an indexed lookup." We'll index the two id columns but leave the two enum columns unindexed.
replies.author: fil512

timeline.bodyText: If we're promoting this class to the core library, I think I'd recommend renaming the normalizeString method to normalizeStringforSearchIndexing or something along those lines, since it's a pretty arbitrary definition of normalizing (but also one that is specifically mandated by the spec)
timeline.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: I'm curious about these optimisticlock annotations.. I don't see any @Version column so I don't think they do anything. Is this deliberate?
timeline.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: I just copy/pasted those from elsewhere.  Gary asked me what it did and I had no idea.  Gary wondered if there was a way to automatically maintain these columns.  If that's what @Version does then we should do this properly
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText: We took another look and decided to just delete these annotations
replies.author: fil512

replies.bodyText:
@Version creates an optimistic lock column, which is useful if you think that both:

there is a chance for two threads to update a row with different values at the same time
this happening would be a bad thing

...or....

you want to make sure that two threads are never touching the same row at the same time

For system processing like this I'd say it's less common for that to be the case. Not unheard of at all though. We have an @Version on BulkExportJobEntity for the second reason for example
replies.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText:
Instead of String.join here you should use ParameterUtil.escapeAndJoinOrList - That method also escapes reserved characters in the strings such as | and ,
..unless you are manually creating strings for token SPs such as system|value in which case that method will hurt you since you don't want the | escaped. If that's the case, at least make sure you're using ParameterUtil.escape on the left and right sides of that statement.. otherwise someone will eventually try to match on a value with a comma and have a horribly hard to diagnose bug
timeline.author: jamesagnew

timeline.bodyText: Ooh two spaces after the period. So uhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh the AP style guide doesn't recommend two spaces after a period so clearly like we can't have that geez
timeline.author: jamesagnew

replies.bodyText: I learned to type in 1979 on a manual typewriter and had two spaces DRILLED into my soul.  I have tried.  I cannot change this.  It is too deeply engrained.
replies.author: fil512
